Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: System of Multimodal Imaging and Point-of-Care Biopsies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is that it may potentially impact the lives of millions of women worldwide who are tested for the presence of endometrial cancer. In the US, women who with abnormal vaginal bleeding (regardless of age, shape, race, economic standing, history or ethnicity) are considered to have endometrial cancer, until proven otherwise. Unfortunately, unlike the use of pap tests for the detection of cervical cancer, no tests or exams currently exist for screening endometrial cancer. Simple and accurate screening and biopsy tools are important for the early detection of endometrial cancer because of: i) clinical requirements to rule out cancer first and foremost, ii) improved survival rates with early detection, and iii) high pain, cost, and time associated with current diagnostic measures. This team's process may enable women to get access to non-invasive, accurate diagnoses of endometrial cancer not otherwise available. Accurate, real time and early diagnosis of endometrial cancer will benefit and estimated one out of nineteen women.

This I-Corps project focuses on the first steps in translating a miniaturized tool for discerning healthy vs. malignant tissue at the point of care. Despite the critical need, no method currently exists for the real time, clinical diagnosis of endometrial cancer. Current methods require a succession of inconclusive, invasive, and time-consuming tests, thus failing to meet the needs of the user. To fill this gap, this projects aims to develop a product for screening endometrial cancer during the first visit to a clinic. Two imaging modalities are integrated, including photoacoustic imaging (known to provide a clear map of vasculature, and ultrasound) for deep tissue penetration, identifying tissue density. This combination will enable the detection of tissue not otherwise able to be reached without expensive and invasive procedures requiring contrast agents. This new method of device manipulation will allow for complete 3D imaging of an organ, in conjunction with tissue sample collection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals of the project

This award provided funding for the UsPai Diagnostics, at Arizona State University, to obtain customer feedback and provide insight regarding our: i) products’ role in the market, and ii) needs of the user. By identifying and implementing user feedback into our current imaging technology, we aim to create a product with the ability to save lives through the early detection of endometrial cancer. 

 

Major Activities

The major activities included: i) interviewed total 130 customers (over 100 in-person and 115 during ICorps), ii) participated in 2 workshops, iii) refined the business model canvas, iv) identified a clear product­-market fit, v) developed a product prototype (miniature photoacoustic and ultrasound imaging probe), vi) initiated a company for further development this product, viii) submitted proposal for additional funding through an NSF STTR, and ix) awarded two follow-up grants on this technology: (a) $100,000 through the Women and Philanthropy Foundation and (b) $25,000 through Edson.

 

Specific Objectives

1. interview over 100 end users

The success of UsPai in ICorps was shown through the third highest number of total interviews of the entire ICorps cohort, and the largest number (>100) of in­ person interviews. The UsPai group utilized LaunchPad Central for collecting and analyzing data obtained from customer interviews.

 

2. identify a product-market fit

Interviews performed with this grant showed that physicians require a tool to provide them with eyes, where they are currently going in blind. Successful technology will minimize pain and time for the patient, provide a clear diagnosis to the physician, and reduce unnecessary repeat visits to the hospital. The physician requires a way to prove, without a doubt, the presence or absence of cancer in real time. Combining the two currently used modalities, i) imaging and ii) biopsy, the customer will be confident of their diagnosis for endometrial cancer. The proposed technology presents an innovative, accessible, and more effective method and device for 3D imaging of the endometrium.

 

3. refine a business model

These results are undoubtedly our most outstanding scientific achievement, but our group went further, identifying the market potential for our product. The total available market size for our product was calculated based on the 2015 global USI device market size, valued at $6.833 Billion USD. Serviceable available market (SAM), or that market that is specifically being sold to OB/GYNs is 21% of the overall USI market, valued at ~ $1.8 Billion. Our target market is estimated at 10% of the SAM, resulting in ~ $180 Million.

 

4. obtain further funding

$125,000 in further funding has since been awarded through two sources:

  • $100,000 through the Women and Philanthropy Foundation
  • $25,000 through Edson, Angel funding source at Arizona State University

 

5. disseminate the knowledge gained to the scientific and greater communities

Dissemination:

  • Invited talk to the Women and Philanthropy Foundation (Fall 2017)
  • Invited talk to the Department of Biomedical Engineering at Colorado State University (Spring 2018)

Student Learning:

  • Graduate Student Research: Christopher Miranda
  • Undergraduate Student Research: Victoria Tai, Blake Browning, Madeleine Howell, Amar Joshi

Course presentations:

  • Arizona State University (BME 182, BME 598, FSE 150, SOS 394)
  • Colorado State University (BIOM 592-801)

Published manuscript:

  • Presentation and Award for Christopher Miranda's Poster Presentation at BMES National Conference, 2017.
  • Christopher Miranda, Joel Barkley, Barbara S. Smith, "Intrauterine photoacoustic and ultrasound imaging probe," J. Biomed. Opt. 23(4), 046008 (2018), doi: 10.1117/1.JBO.23.4.046008.

      http://dx.doi.org/10.1117/1.JBO.23.4.046008

Company Formation

  • OptoAcoustics, LLC

Patent Submission:

  • SYSTEMS FOR MULTIMODAL REAL­TIME IMAGING FOR BIOPSIES AND RELATED METHODS. Patent No. AZTE.P0134US.P1. UNITED STATES. Application Date

 

Highlights

Based on 130 preliminary interviews, we learned that physicians require a tool to provide them with eyes, where they are currently going in blind. Successful technology will minimize pain and time for the patient, provide a clear diagnosis to the physician, and reduce unnecessary repeat visits to the hospital. The physician requires a way to prove, without a doubt, the presence or absence of cancer in real time. Combining the two currently used modalities, i) imaging and ii) biopsy, the customer will be confident of their diagnosis for endometrial cancer. The proposed technology presents an innovative, accessible, and more effective method and device for 3D imaging of the endometrium. 

Highlights of these efforts include EI participation on a symposium panel, further funding proposals, and the formation of a company. Information regarding the grant was disseminated through product translation discussions within an undergraduate course (Introduction to Biomedical Product Design and Development, 135 students, Fall 2017), and a graduate course (Technologies for Global Health, 22 students, Fall 2017, 2018), at Arizona State University ­ given by the PI, Barbara Smith. We maintain ongoing schedules of talks and hands-­on activities for broad audiences, often join in cooperation with public science programs at ASU, and nationally.

 


Last Modified: 05/20/2018
Modified by: Barbara Smith
